texts.shortText: Medium-sized, off-white isopod. Antennae short, reaching only about a third length of thorax; antenna 1 with the first few segments swollen (but not bent outwards at right-angles, as in Eurydice). Second antennae slender. Upper lip (epistome) coming to a sharp point that projects upwards between bases on antennae. Pleotelson with a pair of lateral concavities and both uropods and pleotelson fringed with fairly-long setae.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Mozambique.
Fairly common burrowing into sandy beaches and especially in sand around rocks where it scavenges on washed up debris.
Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.

The only regional representative of this genus, but found together with species of Right-angles beach louse (Eurydice species) with which it is often confused.  Eurydice are distinguished by having the first antennae initially project forward and then turn outwards at right angles after the first segment.

Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa. 3. Additions to the marine Isopoda, with notes on some previously incompletely known species. Annals of the South African Museum, 10 (11), 359-440.

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 74, as Pontogeloides latipes).
